docs.lead_paragraph: Two strikingly different pictures of Tabitha Walrond were drawn yesterday in opening statements at her trial on charges of second-degree manslaughter in the starvation death of the infant son she had been breast-feeding. Robert Holdman, an assistant district attorney, depicted Ms. Walrond, 21, as a woman scorned, so angry at the father of her child for taking a new girlfriend that she wanted an abortion, tried to shut the baby's paternal relatives out of his life, and let her son starve to death at 2 months, on Aug. 27, 1997.

headline.main: Trial Begins for Mother in Breast-Fed Infant's Starvation Death

docs.abstract: Trial of Tabitha Walrond on charges of second-degree manslaughter in starvation death of infant son she had been breast-feeding begins, Bronx; opening statements noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE big question right now about Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican from Suffolk County, is whether he is audacious or a fool. Consider that Mr. Lazio, who looks more like Beaver Cleaver than most other members of Congress, continues to say that he may well challenge Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for the Republican nomination for Senate in New York. Consider that after Mr. Giuliani went to Washington last week for a snuggle with Republican senators who want the Mayor to run, Mr. Lazio dismissed it as so much grandstanding.

headline.main: Of a Politician, and What Makes Him Run

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles career of Representative Rick A Lazio, Republican from Suffolk County who is considering running for US Senate next year; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Japan normally takes many years, even decades, to approve foreign medications. But last year the middle-aged men who run the Ministry of Health and Welfare decided to rush the process for an American drug that they apparently deemed so critical that Japan could not wait another moment. It is Viagra.

headline.main: Japan's Tale of Two Pills: Viagra and Birth Control

docs.abstract: Japan, only industrialized country that still has not approved use of modern version of birth-control pill for women, is now in throes of mania for Viagra, little blue pills that treat impotence; Japan normally takes many years, even decades, to approve foreign medication, but middle-aged men who run Ministry of Health and Welfare decide to rush process for Viagra, apparently deemed so critical that Japan could not wait another minute; if issue of sex and impotence has surfaced more openly, so has starker political issue about tilted status of men over women in Japan; low-dose birth control pill, most common form of nonsurgical contraception in Unted States, still has not won approval, even though its application was filed decade ago; women's groups are furious (L)
docs.snippet: Japan normally takes many years, even decades, to approve foreign medications. But last year the middle-aged men who run the Ministry of Health and Welfare decided to rush the process for an American drug that they apparently deemed so critical that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care, a new national survey confirms with a range of new statistics. This research raises concern among minority leaders that two separate and unequal systems of care have developed in the United States. The survey was conducted by Morehouse College of Medicine, a predominantly black institution in Atlanta, and the New American Wellness Group, a communications and marketing company that focuses on minority health care issues.

headline.main: Health Care Systems in U.S. Called Separate and Unequal

docs.abstract: New national survey finds that middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care; research raises concerns among minority leaders that two separate and unequal systems of care have developed in United States; survey was conducted by Morehouse College of Medicine, predominanlty black institution in Atlanta, and New American Wellness Group, communications and marketing company that focuses on minority health care issues; among findings is that far fewer blacks and Hispanics than whites have a doctor of their own race or ethnicity (M)
docs.snippet: Middle-income blacks, Hispanics and whites have significantly different attitudes toward health care, a new national survey confirms with a range of new statistics. This research raises concern among minority leaders that two separate and unequal...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Governor's Children's Health Insurance Work Group announced programs last week to help low-income working parents pay for health insurance and day care for their children. One plan would earmark more than $17.7 million to subsidize policies for about 72,000 children whose parents can buy employer-sponsored health insurance. The panel also supported a pending bill that would eliminate a six-month waiting period before some children can qualify for New Jersey Kidcare, which offers free and low-cost health insurance. The bill would affect about 4,500 children whose parents buy their own insurance but earn less than $33,400, twice the Federal poverty level for a family of four. About 30,000 children are enrolled in Kidcare. About 328,000 children in the state currently have no health insurance at all, said Ed Rogan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services.

headline.main: Whitman Panel Proposes Plans To Insure More Children

docs.abstract: New Jersey Gov Christine Whitman's Children's Health Insurance Work Group announces programs to help low-income working parents pay for health insurance and day care for children (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S not easy to quiet a crowd of 1,000, especially when they are Nassau County Democrats at a party convention. But moments after Democratic delegates chose Thomas P. DiNapoli as their new chairman 10 days ago, he tried to do just that. ''Shhh. Do you hear it? Do you hear it?'' he said into the microphone, holding a forefinger to his lips and cupping his other hand to his ear. Puzzled party members stopped milling about the stuffy hall at Hofstra University, and the din began to subside.

headline.main: Nassau Democrats Reorganize, But Can They Stay That Way?; Local Party Prepares to Battle G.O.P. and Its Own Quarrelsome Nature

docs.abstract: About 1,000 Nassau County Democrats attend party convention at which they appoint Thomas P DiNapoli as chairman; party, which has reputation for infighting, hopes for real gains against Republicans, weakened by county budget deficit; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, removed the Acting Superintendent and four board members from Community School District 14 yesterday in an attempt, he said, to root out the corruption that allowed a Brooklyn rabbi to steal $6 million from the district during the course of two decades. The housecleaning is the most sweeping use of a 1996 law that gave Dr. Crew broad powers to dismiss local superintendents and board members for malfeasance. In the past, Dr. Crew has suspended entire school boards and removed members, but he has never ousted more than one member at once.

headline.main: Crew Removes 5 in District Tainted by Corruption Case

docs.abstract: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew ousts four Community School District 14 board members and reassigns Acting Superintendent John Musico in effort to root out corruption that allowed Rabbi Hertz Frankel to siphon money from public schools and give it to private Jewish girls' school; says two board members, Leopold Lefkowitz and Harold Klagsbald, admitted they knew about scheme but said they did not think it was illegal; holds two others, board president Juan Martinez and Isaac Brauner, failed to oversee district properly and should have stopped scheme; notes Musico cooperated with probe; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: How tragic and cynical that Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin is flaunting the success of his welfare reform policy through the example one Milwaukee woman, Michelle Crawford (front page, April 20). The courage Ms. Crawford has shown getting off welfare is impressive, but he obviously has no clue about her true challenges and realities. What all of us, and especially people like Ms. Crawford, should be worried about is that this is often how policy is made -- in a vacuum.

headline.main: Off Welfare, Life Is Still Tough

docs.abstract: Dr Alan Shapiro letter finds it tragic and cynical that Wisconsin Gov Tommy Thompson flaunts success of his welfare reform through example of one woman, Michelle Crawford

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly all the Federal Government's computers will be ready for the year 2000, and so will those of most states, but those of some local governments and small businesses will not be, the official supervising computer preparation for 2000 said today. The official, John A. Koskinen, chairman of the President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion, also predicted that some hospitals and other health care providers could have financial trouble that could force them to close because billing and reimbursement systems would not work.

headline.main: Some Local Governments Unprepared for 2000, Report Says

docs.abstract: John A Koskinen, chairman of President's Council of Year 2000 Conversion, reports nearly all Federal Govt's computers will be ready for Year 2000, as will those of most states, but that those of some local governments and small businesses will not; predicts some hospitals and other health care providers could have financial trouble that could force them to close because billing and reimbursement systems will not work (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Child psychologists and other experts on youth violence say the killings in Colorado on Tuesday are evidence of a woeful lack of mental health services for young people at a time of decreasing family strength and increasing access to the tools of violence. They also said parents, teachers and students themselves ought to be receiving training in the early detection of depression and violent tendencies. But they added that the continuing stigma of mental illness and cutbacks in health insurance due to managed care were keeping society from looking frankly at the problem.

headline.main: Experts Urge Swift Action to Fight Depression, Isolation and Aggression

docs.abstract: Child psychologists and other experts on youth violence say killings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo, are evidence of woeful lack of mental health services for young people at time of decreasing family strength and increasing access to tools of violence; photo (M)
